author: sky.cactus
content: Has there been discussion previously at all of using zkSTARKS to prove chain history so people can skip to latest block without having to download all previous blocks or acquire latest block hash from a trusted source?

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think zkSTARK tech is advanced enough to prove an EVM transaction, but I'm still curious about the technique and possible future uses of it.

author: lightclient
content: <@!301186049323958275> Celo has an ultra light client called "Plumo", i don't know much about it but i believe they use recursive snarks to prove history

author: lightclient
content: there was a nice sbc talk about it last year

author: ralexstokes
content: as i understand it, the high-level idea is to make a snark attesting to a zkp that some light client committee did their job correctly, much like we are shipping in altair for the beacon chain

author: ralexstokes
content: it would be quite cool to eventually see something like this for the beacon chain!

author: ralexstokes
content: you would still have to deal w/ weak subjectivity but could imagine a proof that lets you skip all of the verification work to get to the head if you were offline for some time

author: ralexstokes
content: one caveat is that the current tech for recursive snarks involves two (aiui heavy) elliptic curves so we would have all of the overhead involved in deploying yet another curve at the base layer
